title: How many people in the U.S. will have received one or more doses of a COVID-19 vaccine as of 28 February 2021, according to the CDC?
preds: 72,806,180  Jabs 48,435,536  ppl Leaving the door open a tad for Tadpole just in case

CDC says 48,435,536 receiving at least 1 dose as of Feb 27 2021 at 6:00am ET (data posted at noon on 2/27/21). Today's and tomorrow's numbers (question says as of 2/28/21 at 10pm) would be two additional full days of vaccines to be added with an average of 1.5 million shots per day. It's going to be close but should pass the 50 million mark.

We are currently at 48.4 million with one or more. We've had a maximum of about 2.3 m per day which would put us over the threshold, but recently the rate has been lower, closer to 1.8-1.5 and decreasing. Additionally, some of the lower more recent numbers can be attributed to a delay in reporting, which would also suggest that the number will increase.
With only 24 hours left, the likelihood of more than 1.5M individuals getting a COVID vaccine is incredibly low.

Feb 25 5pm EST is 46,074,392. 
Feb 26 2021 6:00am ET it was up to 47,184,199
Feb 27 2021 6:00am ET 48,435,536.  
Ends Feb 28 at 10pm It is going to be very be close.  Not certain how many vaccines are given on Sundays.  Not certain how many will get reported on Sunday vs Monday.  I am guessing the Sunday numbers will be lower than past few days resulting in under 50m.

As I mentioned in my last update, it looks like the data has been particularly effected this week by delayed reporting. We're at about 48.4M right now, with only 101K reported for yesterday. I expect that number to be closer to 850K when all the numbers have been reported, and I expect today and tomorrow to total another 800K-850K. That would obviously put us over 50K.  Again, however, delayed reporting plays a role here. By tomorrow, the data will likely reflect less than 200K for today and maybe completely missing for tomorrow. SO! I'm gonna come back here tonight and see what the data looks like at 10:00, but for now I'm shifting only slightly to the right.

70,454,064   Jabs 47,184,199  ppl Really do not like it when it is close, need to develop an algorithmic defense strategy.  What worries me is there might be someone saying, come on everyone, lets see if we can get the numbers up past 50 for the month end... and they do.   Will sleep on it, have a look tomorrow and give it the final adjustment

Total number of people vaccinated as of 2/25 5pm EST is 46,074,392.  Feb 26 2021 6:00am ET it was up to 47,184,199.  That pace is a bit faster than I expected.  But the weekend is coming up so it might slow down between now and 10pm on the 28th.  Hedging more it might go over 50m.
Linreg now lower considering recent data, but it also increases faster on the weekends. Feels like a coin flip at this point.
Over 93 million doses have been distributed in the US. One and a half million per day are getting vaccines. By Sunday it may be up to 51 million having received first dose.

CDC is reporting 47 million and the average is 1.5 million a day. We had delays in NY this entire week for the first dose but vaccines are back (appointments were available as of today). This is another one of those GJ questions that veers right on the threshold (my favorite, not lol) https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/biden-vaccine-50-million/2021/02/25/cb36c8ca-77ab-11eb-9537-496158cc5fd9_story.html
Final forecast: as of 28 Feb 2021, 49.55mn people will have received at least one dose of a COVID-19 vaccine.

It actually appears as if we're recovering nicely from the low we saw, presumably due to the extreme weather. I believe there will be some slop in this question due to delayed reporting - I've been watching the "most recent 5 days" numbers, which the CDC points out are squishiest due to the potential for delayed reporting, rise more quickly this week.  If this question closed on 5 March, after all the numbers had a chance to update through 28 FEB, I'd have stayed bullish on breaking the 50K mark. BUT, because the numbers are likely to be underreported when the question closes, I'm staying at below 50K.

There doesn't seem to have been big movement in the number of vaccinations between yesterday and today, so I am lowering my estimation of whether we hit or exceed 50K. It's still a real possibility, but it would require everything going well. And when did that happen?

As of the 26th of February, according to the CDC around 46 million people have received at least one dose of the vaccine. Considering the rate vaccines have been distributed (around 1.5 million doses, not people, a day), it is less likely the number will be above 50 million than below.

CDC count comes in about 2M lower than many other tracking sites, which could be from military counts and other.  Texas may have a backlog of doses to administer.  I could still see a last minute push to get data out to celebrate 50M total by end of February.
68,274,117  Jabs 46,074,392  ppl Close, but as Mr B once said the wiles of winter my undoing
two days out, so pretty much just eyeballing the data at this point
Pretty big jump yesterday, dialing it back a little bit. Only three more days and need about 1.3 million a day so unlikely but not as extreme as I had it before
1.6 million daily; 46,075,000 vaccinated as of today; 2 days left. Just comes up short.

At the moment there are ~46m people who have received a vaccine (either one or two shots). At a rate of 1.4 m shots per day (the current rate) and allowing for a 3:1 split between first and second doses, the likely total is somewhere around 53m+. Assuming some increase in efficiency now that storm slow-downs have subsided, I'm estimating up. Thanks to @Harvey-the-Rabbit for correcting my read of the stats.
Total number of people vaccinated as of 2/25 5pm EST is 46,074,392.  Looks like they are making almost no progress getting new people vaccinated.  All in for under 50m.

The US currently has 45.237 million people that have received one or more dose, according to the CDC.  The NY times lists the current vaccine rate at 1.45 million doses per day.  Assuming approximately half of those does are the second shot, I expect the number of 45.237 million to rise at half that rate, or another 2.9 million by the end of 28 February, for a total of 48.1 million people with one or more shots.
Numbers still look bad. Was hoping for there to be some "delayed reporting" mixed up in there, but the weather obviously hit pretty hard.

There are already 60m + vaccinated (1 or more doses). There is 88,669.035 available doses and if they are distributed at a rate of 1.4m per day, they will add ~6m by the 28th, albeit with 20,607,21 being more or less redundant because they are getting 2nd shots... the total is roughly 63m. Assuming there isn't another major impediment --like a freeze in Texas, they should maintain the current rate. I've allowed a 32% chance they miss the target I've set for unknown obstacles.
At this time there have been more than 66.5 million doses of the vaccine given in the US. https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/covid-vaccine-tracker-global-distribution/
I think that originally I had involved my own hopes in my prediction and then did not adapt my forecast fast enough. I do believe that the final result will be very close to the edge.
Looks like less than 50 million as of today (Thurs) but bias is towards catching up with delays.  Will depend on greater than expected vacs 2/25 and 2/26 and some on weekends.

Data as of 02/24= 45,237,143
Since 2 days (my last forecast) = 1,100,00 (550,000/day)
If 550,000/day during 4 days => fewer than 50,000,000 The Crowd increase for fewer than 50,000,000
No way they'll make it now

-Total current tally is 45,237,143 for '1 or more doses', as at 9:30am GMT 25th Feb
-692K vaccinations reported over last 24 hours
-Leaves 4,762,857 vaccinations left, or 1.19m per day over next 4 reporting days
-Recent 7 day Moving Average for 1st dose is ~658K vaccinations (See Vaccination Trends on CDC link)
-Leave 15% margin of error on 7 day moving average 658K, for total reporting delays over past 3 days = ~98K vaccinations potentially given, but yet to be reported
-Historically, Sundays are far below the 7 day moving average
-Extremely unlikely for the moving average + reporting delays to yield the missing ~2.3M vaccinations to get over the 50M hurdle, even with a 75% upswing in the 7 day moving average over 3 days.
66,464,947   Jabs 45,237,143  ppl Could go either way
The numbers were poor today, under 700k.  50M is not impossible by Feb 28, but it's almost out of reach.  Ironically, within a week or two we could be seeing twice as many vaccinations per day.
Delayed shipments still rippling through system.

It looks like the weather really, really put a hurting on vaccination delivery last week. We were on a steady increase, which I expect us to return to, but given the fact that we were already attempting to maximize our capacity to surge, I don't anticipate that we'll see anything other than a dip & return. In other words, there is no capacity to surge *past* what we were doing pre-weather to "make up for" the dip last week. Essentially, we just lost that time and now we will return to normal.
It really looks like a lot of second shots are being administered, less than 1 million first shots per day and they need more than that rate over next 5 days.
The past week or so has been very disappointing.  Unless there is capacity for 1.1M vaccines per day for the next 5 days we'll be under 50M.  I'll switch my beans to "Fewer than 50,000,000."

count @ 44.5 million as of Feb 23rd. 7 day moving average @ 725k. With 5 days left, 3.5-4 million new 1st person vaccination should be additionally done. ~ 1.1 million average is needed for remaining days to cross 50 million by Feb 28th.

The current vaccine receiving trend looks like a linear equation. According to the data from Feb 14 to Feb 22, there are approximately 730,731 people receiving at least their first vaccine dose. As the line moves to the right, there should be about 48,522,504 people receiving the vaccine dose on Feb 28. There might be an increase due to the encouragement of receiving doses, but there might be other factors such as extreme weather condition affection people to get their vaccine.

Right now, about 44,000,000 people have had one or more doses of the vaccine, and about 1.8 million shots are being given per day. Given that for some people, the shot is their second shot and not adding to the overall number, I predict that fewer than 50,000,000 people will be vaccinated by February 28, but there's still a fairly high possibility that 50,000,000 people could be vaccinated, so I left that probability pretty high as well.

The recent daily rate of "one or more doses" is too low to achieve 50 million such doses by 2/28/21. Haven't seen a one million+ daily count for these since 2/16/21. https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations
Vaccines are rolling out now Quickly. There is consideration of using the extra doses in vials.
Supply has been slower  than anticipated.

Historical growth trend 11.5 million doses ending Feb 18th, 9.6 million doses ending Feb 11, 8.9 million doses endinf Feb 4th (Economist). Estimated 13.6 million doses ending Feb 25th (19% growth weekly). Currently 44.38 + 13.6/6days left (69% of one dose vs. all doses) = 52.55

Affirming my forecast (at around 7PM eastern) with the note that 44,138,118 people are currently shown on the CDC website as having received a first dose.  That means another 977,000 per day will need to receive first doses for the next six days to exceed 50,000,000.

There is a lag of 5 days in data reporting. For the purpose of this question, the data reported as of 10:00PM ET on 28 February 2021will be considered. That means the actual number of vaccinations for 24-28th February will be under reported.
Delays from storm. Moving to lower bins.

Snow and potentially a CDC methodology change seem to have caused a drop in recent vaccinations. Looks like a good chance it stays under 50 million. Info on the methodology change: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/live-blog/2021-01-21/methodology-and-analysis-for-the-covid-19-vaccine-tracker#60319089B2240006
Changing my mind.  The big storm delayed a lot of vaccine shipments, and caused some distribution centers to close.  With the storm passing, I expect a catch-up bump this week.
The data is headed straight for 50,000,000; it could go either way.  Gotta check this one every day.
Think true probability is more like 2:1 but I basically had discounted this bucket until today

The (recent) rate of "1 or more doses" needs to increase to near one million per day to exceed 50 million on 2/28/21. https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations

I switched to 100% below 50m.
43628092 on Feb 22, an increase of 5335822 to a week earlier.
43628092  + 5335822  = 48963914 (which would be the projection for March 1st).

On 7th February, the count is 34.2m. On 14th Feb, the count is 40.4m. That's a +5.8m increase. If we are to extrapolate that, it means by 28th Feb, it will be 52m. However, there are two arguments why that may not happen: - CDC claimed that their data has a 5 days lag. This means by the time GJ Open checked the data on 28th Feb 10 pm, the count will only accurately reflect the data up to 23rd Feb, partially reflect the data for 24th - 26th, and almost non-existent for 27th-28th. The last two days alone, from extrapolation, normally account for 1.5m shots. - We're seeing signs that the vaccine distribution may be slowing down from 15th to 22 Feb, presumably due to a snowstorm. Power cuts are reported, stopping the government from distributing the vaccines since refrigerators to keep them cool are off. It is possible that when the snow ends, the vaccination resumes since the vaccines have been restocked, but I am skeptical if there is a big surge since the speed of injecting the vaccine will be a choke point. Currently, the trend is from 14th-21th, they will be performing at 80% of capacity. So, if we do the math By 14th Feb: 40.4 m
By 21th Feb: +5.8m x 80%  = 4.6m => 45m
By 28th Feb: +5.8m - 1.5m = 50.8m - 1.5 = 49.3m
Rate needs to increase by about 100,000 doses a day, but Texas should just about be able to do that.

It does look like the weather hit vaccination distribution pretty hard. In fact, it looks like the totals are down about 40%. And it looks like the proportion of total doses going to "new arms" is sitting at about 50%. We are only at about 43.6M doses as of today. The rate of increase in our 7-day moving average has dropped fairly significantly (again, I believe weather-related), so it looks like we've continued to sit at about 1.5M per day.  So BL is that we lost some new arms last week due to the weather, but I think we'll pick back up again this week now that the weather has passed. If we figure another 750K-1M new arms per day this week, we're probably looking at north of 50M, especially given the lagging numbers (17-20 FEB are still squishy).

The CDC vaccine distribution count is currently at 43.6M with 7 days left.  Although the winter storms last week delayed 6M vaccines, about 800K vaccines were administered per day over the last 5 days.  2M of the 6M delayed vaccines have already been delivered and the other 4M will be delivered by mid-week according to recent news sources.  This indicates that next week we will see an increase in vaccine administrations across the United States.   https://www.cnbc.com/2021/02/21/covid-white-house-to-ship-millions-of-vaccines-this-week-delayed-by-winter-storm.html 50M-43.628M = 6.372M remaining to reach 50M administered
6.372M/7 days = 910K per day
These is lower than the average daily rate of 1M that was administered before the storm If you add the additional vaccines to that number, there is an incredibly high likelihood that there will be 50M-53M people receiving 1 or more vaccine doses by the end of February.

43.6m today, with 7 reporting days left (ok may have been a day out on my counts before) but that is still 914k per day, 100k higher than the recent trend which was 825k per day to 16th Feb and taking a downturn.

Currently on track for ~50M, assuming ~800k vaccinations per day (current 7 day average). Trending downwards, presumably because of the bad weather (?), so might take a few days to get back to trend, though maybe it'll recover quickly. Doesn't seem possible to be above 53M.

Winter storm didn't result in as big a dip as I'd expected in the recent data, revising to 50M+ bucket up. Texas only dipped 31% and they were the worst hit area, the whole US slope hardly changed over the last few days.  Not really sure why more of a dip didn't happen, maybe people are largely used to winter storms and also value vaccination very highly. Not sure there's a neat and tidy explanation though, all of the curves for COVID topics seem so incredibly slow to respond or completely unresponsive to what you hear in the news. It feels like for most of these a fair outside rate assessment will probably get you 95% of the way there.

Clear that the rate has slowed very significantly as a result of bad weather. I'm totally uncertain about how quickly they will be able to catch up though, and that really is the only relevant question now, as I don't think doses are getting destroyed by the power cuts (or not in any great numbers). I assume that once they get things running smoothly again, they will resume vaccinating at a higher rate than they were previously.

Linreg since the 15th gives 88/12 for >50M/<50M, but what's concerning is the huge storm knocking out power in large chunks of the country which will likely delay deliveries. The linreg puts the value at 50,717,000, so the daily rate over the next several days doesn't have to dip by that much for us to come in low. I don't overweight the <50M option though due to the US's change in policy of not holding vaccines for second doses which will (hopefully) free up more doses in the coming weeks and inflate the # of persons getting at least one dose even with production held constant.
The storms are delaying vaccination in many parts of the state

Thanks to @SMG558 it's come to my attention that the numbers I was using for proportion of total doses that were second doses was actually low. It does look like it's varying between 30%-50% right now... SO! I gotta adjust again. We're at about 40M today. We're looking at about 1.5M doses/day (7-day moving average). Although we had seen each progressive week raise over the week prior, the last two weeks we have solid data for make it look like we may have leveled off. So if we look at something a little more like ~35% as the number of new doses that are actually second doses, we're looking at more like 975K-1M "new arms" per day.  I think all that funky new math still puts us at right about 55M by the end of the period. It'll be interesting to see how the weather impacted things, if at all. Something to keep an eye on.

I used excel to create a simple linear model of people vaccinated by day using this data (https://github.com/owid/covid-19-data/blob/master/public/data/vaccinations/country_data/United%20States.csv). I ran two models, one from Jan 14 when vaccination rates were more stable, and one for the whole dataset. On Feb 28, they predicted 53.4 million and 61.2 million, respectively. The average of the two is 57.3. This lands square in the 56-59 million range. As others have pointed out, cold weather may slow vaccination rates, and some people may start getting a second dose, reducing the total number of people who have received a vaccine.

As noted by others the CDC reports a significant drop to around 600,000 "1 or More Doses" administered, for 2/17/21. An average of nearly 900,000 such doses per day is currently needed to exceed 50 million over the eleven remaining days in this question. (https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations) Raising forecast for the first question category mainly from ongoing weather-related concerns in large parts of the U.S. (https://www.cnn.com/2021/02/15/weather/winter-storms-covid-19-vaccine/index.html)

If you do the math based on when this prediction ends and use 1.49 million people/day as an average of vaccines given out, it will give you around 65.16 million people who will have the vaccine by the end of February.

The cumulative proportion of first doses to total doses administered has been decreasing, from 86% as of January 17, to 72% as of February 14.  As you would expect, though, the proportion has been changing more rapidly week by week, with 80% of the doses being first doses in the week ending January 24, to 51% in the week ending February 14.   There is still a backlog of people who haven't gotten their second doses, however.  It can't quite be determined from the information available, but 52% of the doses administered have been Pfizer, and 48% Moderna--so on average the elapsed time for on-time second doses would be around 24 to 25 days, and only 70+% have gotten theirs on time (also, there are almost 24 million people who have received one, but not both doses).   In order to hit 50 million first doses, there would need to be over 836,000 administered per day for the next two weeks.  In order to hit 53 million first doses, there would need to be about 1.05 million administered per day. Let's say that for the next couple of weeks deliveries are relatively stable (I can't find any news suggesting that they'll be ramping up significantly in this time frame).  And let's say that the first dose/ second dose ratio levels out at about 1:1.   In order to hit the 50 million target, 1.672 million doses would need to be administered per day.  For the 53 million target, it would need to be over 2 million.  This could be accomplished by drawing down on the delivered-but-not-yet-administered stocks, but I am skeptical that it will happen.

Second doses have priority.  For over two weeks the number of first doses has remained relatively flat at ~950k/day; second doses have more than doubled over that timeframe.  See https://covid19-projections.com/path-to-herd-immunity/. If the available number of doses remains constant the number of second doses should climb until it equals the number of first doses.  Only if the total available doses continues to increase can the number of first doses resume its climb.  I'll bet on modestly increasing total vaccinations and only a small increase in first doses, with a mean estimate of 52.8M.

Mean of about 56 million, right-skewed as rollout ramps up. Slight chance of something going wrong dragging it down. Most recent figure from CDC is 38 million having at least 1 dose, with ~1 million per day at the moment.

Almost 2 million doses are administered on a good day. The 7 day average is 1,67 million as of today (including both doses so it doesn't mean 1,67 million new patients). 14 days left until the deadline. I shoot for Bin B and C.

At 39M with 14 days to go.  Biden's stated goal being 1M per day and on average that seems to be about what we're getting, which puts us at 53M.  I'd go about 50/50 on either side of 53M, but I'd bias more on something slowing things down than on something speeding things up in the short term.  Winter weather being just one possibility.  The large vaccine sites being set up can't run at full capacity due to supply, and increased supply will take time to arrive.

The reported data is a bit confusing.  As of 2/11, 48,410,558 doses administered.  Of those, 12,085,830 have received 2 shots.  So 24,171,660 of those doses went to 12,085,830 people.  That leaves 24,238,898 with one dose or 36,324,728 total people (vs 35,834,855 reported).  In any case, it appears about 24m people have only one dose.   There have been 69,014,725 delivered and 48,410,558 administered.  The ~20m difference will be needed to cover those needing the second dose.  So those won't add to the totals.  There has been talk of not holding back vaccine for the second dose (administer all 7m ASAP).  There has been pushback on that and based on current numbers, I don't see how they can do that and still give the second vaccine in a timely manner.   Current Moderna allocations are about 3.5m a week for first doses and a similar amount for second doses (which is shipped 3 weeks later).  Pfizer is at about 2m a week.  That means just under 6m a week in new vaccine.  States are getting better at putting shots in arms, so it seems safe to bet another 15-18m new vaccines will be given in the next few weeks.  36m+15 = 51m to 54m seems a likely outcome. Seven day moving average on 2/2 was 1.4m a day https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccination-trends.  But that probably represents a spike due to getting already allocated vaccine into arms.  On the other hand, there has been a lot more vaccine "allocated" than distributed.  This might go up in the next few weeks.  So 50-53 most likely and more than this high likelihood than fewer.

According to the CDC, as of Feb. 9, the number of people receiving 1 or more doses is 32,867,213. https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccination-trends For that metric, the 7 day moving average currently shows a daily increase of between 850,000 and 1 million people per day. (I am looking at the 7 day moving average for the daily increase in number of people receiving 1 or more doses, because looking at the daily vaccine administration rate will be deceptive, as some of the people receiving the vaccine will be receiving their second dose. This will increase the number of vaccines administered, but will not increase the number of people receiving one or more doses, because they have already been counted.) If the first time vaccination rate stays relatively flat, this would mean that by Feb 28, between 48,167,213 and 50,867,213 will have received at least one dose of the vaccine. However, the first time vaccination rate is likely increasing as the distribution becomes more efficient. Biden has set a target vaccination rate of 1 million doses administered per day, and the New York Times estimates that the rate could be as high as 1.5 million per day. Assuming that we hit a rate of 1.5 million doses per day immediately and remain there until Feb 28, this gives a high end estimate of about 59,800,000.

In any case, we dropped to a very low low of about half a million a couple of days ago, but then rocketed up to 2.2M on the 6th. Current number of people vaccinated at least once (3rd Feb): 27m
Current rate of doses administered (3rd Feb): 1.3m
Rate of doses administered a week ago: 1.12m required daily average to reach 50m: 0.95m
required daily average to reach 53m: 1.08m
required daily average to reach 56m: 1.21m Assuming we are in the scaling limit (i.e. 50% are the 2nd doses and don't count for this question) this means last week there were 0.56m and this week 0.65m new first dosed people. Linearly extrapolating the rate of increase ends us with around 1.9m one Feb28, barely enough for the 50m total. There are three caveats which make me go non-zero at 50-56:
a) we are probably not yet at a 50:50 split for 1st and 2nd doses, rendering the estimates above slightly pessimistic (in terms of this question)
b) some of the reason for the mediocre usage is the Trump administration's hands-off approach. The new administration at least shows active interest which gives a chance for bringing reducing the O(20m) doses which are in the pipeline but not injected.
c) new vaccines becoming available. This is the big unknown in that we do not know when and how much new doses will become available and how long it takes to scale the administration capacity accordingly. I guess it's mostly c) that is required to actually surpass 50m by the end of the month, so I'll be reducing 50+ probabilities over time
Lot of double jabbing going on, so numbers are....  a little brought down

Based on
https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/02/02/fact-sheet-president-biden-announces-increased-vaccine-supply-initial-launch-of-the-federal-retail-pharmacy-program-and-expansion-of-fema-reimbursement-to-states/
and the CDC figure on "Total Doses Distributed" of 57.489.675 (as of 04 February 2021), with roughly three weeks to go until resolution, this limits the number of total distribution projected to roughly 88mn doses.
At a "administration/distribution" rate of currently 60% this means that only 53.5mn doses will realistically be administered by 28 February 2021, unless the administration will be more effective and swift after distribution, and the rate thus increases. Severe winter weather in the northern states could slow down all processes that I understand as part of the administration (checks on charges/quality control, analysis of supply/demand situation in counties, planning and delivery to the actual vaccination site) for the next two weeks, and cancelled appointments due to road conditions could counter and nil the effect of increased distribution entirely.
Even under a very optimistic assumption that the figures Number of "People Receiving 1 or More Doses" and "Total Doses Administered" will approach 66% in the medium term according to the share of one-shot-regimen vaccines and two-shot-regimen vaccines with first doses growing faster than second doses (thus, the respective rate People Receiving 1 or More Doses/Total Doses Administered could approach ca. 80% at maximum when second doses are entirely neglected), there is still the number of people receiving their second dose only, which will not add to the total under scrutiny, and with hindsight to the fact that all vaccines currently administered - BioNTech/Pfizer, Moderna - are currently two-doses-regimens unless the CDC changes its strategy for a first-shots-first strategy, second doses (currently at a rate of 400k on average a day) could subtract as many as 8mn doses from the maximum possible, which leaves us at 46mn or even less. A ten per cent increase of people vaccinated versus initial projection would be a giant step, but however desirable and welcome it will be, it will be hard to achieve. The initiative to source pharmacies and even WalMart as vaccination sites could in the medium term have such an effect, but beginning on 11 February only and on a limited scale, the impact on the outcome of this question will be minor. An estimate is between 47 and 49mn, due to unexpected effects in the distribution chain that I'm unaware of, and a possibly varying lag time of reporting and accuracy. If the involvement of pharmacies after 11 February 2021 changes the "administration/distribution" rate significantly, perhaps to 65% to70% due to less complex distribution, existing and established distribution routes, the outcome will look much differently. This effect will be seen from the data no sooner than 15 February 2021, and the maximum possible figure could reach up to 56mn, with the currently available two vaccines. Only with unconstrained fresh supply confirmed by producers, the stored capacity (Total Doses Delivered minus Total Doses Administered) will converge towards zero, since the necessary storage quota ["stored capacity"/(Number of People Receiving 1 or More Doses minus Number of People Receiving 2 Doses)], currently around 80%, can sink below 50%.
https://us.cnn.com/2021/02/04/us/covid-19-vaccine-drug-stores/index.html First and foremost, currently there are mostly "low hanging fruits " harvested, which means hospital staff and other people that are easy to reach are vaccinated first, according to phase 1 of the vaccination. Once these are done, other groups in the next phase may kick in where  first doses could prove more difficult to administer.  An EUA by the FDA for the Janssen (J&J) single shot regime vaccine, which reportedly could happen "next week" (I expect at some point between 10 to 15 February 2021) is the huge wild card: due to massive pre-production, delivery could start at once (possibly it has already started), and it's the time span it takes from distribution to the status of "administered" which is unclear, but which will impact, for how many days before 28 February an estimated extra number of up to 1mn doses will be inoculated, and whether the statement:
"Building on last week’s announcement, the Biden-Harris Administration will increase overall, weekly vaccine supply to states, Tribes, and territories to 10.5 million doses nationwide beginning this week. This is a 22% increase since taking office on January 20." refers to the initiation of the Janssen vaccine only, or whether it refers to the two already available vaccines only (in a cautious mode due to remaining uncertainties about a third EUA), or a combination of both. A final forecast will thus not be possible until estimated total deliveries of Janssen's vaccine for February will be available, and thus likely not before 20 February 2021.
The question's bins indicate or suggest there's a possibility of much larger numbers of people vaccinated on 28 February, but my overall impression is that this is misleading. EDIT:
It appears that a decision about a EUA request by Janssen (J&J) will not be made before 26 February 2021, according to
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1228901
and will thus not interfere with this question.

As of February 4, about 1.3 million vaccines are administered per day. Multiplied by the 24 days until February 28, that's about 31.2 million vaccines that will be administered by February 28. About 27.8 million people have already been vaccinated, so that would bring the total to 59 million vaccines.

New vaccinations have fallen off a cliff over the past three days.  According to https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/covid-vaccine-tracker-global-distribution/?sref=x7nYEkiY, 63% of shots delivered have been injected.  ND has administered over 90% of their inventory, and WV over 82%.  It's difficult to utilize 100% of delivered vaccines because of logistical issues (cold chain).  And there are time lags in data reporting, so some geographies may actually have run out. So it appears that, at least in some geographies, vaccinations are hitting a wall.  States that have done the best job of getting shots in arms will have to pause and wait for new shipments.  A key question: how long will the pause last? Looking at the Data from the CDC COVID Data Tracker (https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations) the total number of vaccines distributed is at 55,943,800. The number of doses administered is 33, 878,254. If we are to follow the vaccination trend, there is a noticeable decline in the vaccination rate since the beginning of February.  The average so far for February is 457,343 vaccines administered per day. There should be 12,805,604 vaccines administered during the month of February. Which if we add to the 33 million number should give us roughly 46,683,858 doses administered total. With all those numbers considered by the end of February, there is a reasonable assumption that the number of doses administered will increase. Although the probability that it will exceed 50,000,000 low.
As of 3 Feb, 27,154,956. Will need to revisit prior to closeout, but issues with delivery and access will limit distribution. https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations

President Biden has pledged to have 150M COVID vaccines administered by his 100th day in office, which ends around April 30th.  This assumes that these rates are met and that the Johnson & Johnson vaccine does not significantly impact distribution before the end of February. https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/150-million-vaccinations-tracker-biden-goal-n1255716 Averaged, that is 1.5M vaccines per day.  The CDC lists 27.1M Americans as having received one or more vaccine doses.  There are 25 days left in February. (1.5M * 25) = 37.5M - more vaccines that will be administered in February There are 6.5M that have received 2 or more doses.  Given that the remaining 20.7M (number of people that have 1 or more doses - number of people that have both doses), will need their second dose before the end of the month, one can assume 20.7M vaccines of the 37.5M will be second dose vaccines. 37.5M - 20.7M = 16.8M - the additional individuals that will receive their first vaccine 16.8M (add'l individuals receiving dose 1) + 27.1M (individuals who already received 1 or more doses) = 43.94M For the upper limit, if all 37.5M vaccines go to individuals that haven't received the vaccine with no second doses:
37.5M + 27.1M = 64.6M - 
> 65M is only possible if another vaccine comes on line or distribution quantities surpass President Biden's goal

By the end of next month another 27 million doses will be going out to people who have already received a dose based on CDC data. Unless we switch to a first doses first strategy. Currently the US is averaging around 1.3 million doses a day. I'm pretty confident based on manufacturing projections, the slow ramp up in injection volume, and the number of doses already held back that the US will average over 2 million doses a day through February, with around half of that being first doses. Here are some big factors at play: 1.) Many states and hospitals are (stupidly, in my opinion) holding back second doses. So although it seems like the US is going to use up all its available doses on second doses this month, that's not the case since many states still have a huge stock of doses not administered.
2.) Getting shots in arms seems to be the biggest bottleneck. So it's possible that when more second doses come due injecting those eats up most of the injection capacity. I think this is probably unlikely, as they're starting the transition to pharmacies and most states are rolling into the second phase and my guess is the increased demand is going to kick some of these vaccination programs in gear.
3.) Vaccine supply is not going to be a problem for long, though in the short term of the month of February it's less clear how large supply will be. Pfizer and Moderna's projections combine for a total of 200 million doses by the end of March. So they're planning on ramping up fast. The big question to me is how fast injections can ramp up.
4.) Johnson and Johnson could be approved in a few weeks, and probably will have doses manufactured, but it sounds like it could be less than 10 million doses shipped out in February, so the role they play in this will probably be very small. Based on these factors I would guess an average of at least a million doses a day of first shots. An average of another million a day of second shots is needed to keep up with second doses. But with about 20 million doses already held in reserve it's just a matter of whether injections can scale up, and I think they can now that pharmacies are getting involved and more of the general public is eligible. If we stick with the inflexible 2 dose priority I think the ceiling is probably averaging like 1.5 million new shots a day so 65 million. But if we switch to be more flexible on the second dose I think there's a good chance 65+ could happen easily, I just think the chances of being less flexible on second doses are on the low side. Based on all that I'm going with this boring distribution centered around 56 to 59 million, which would be 1.2 to 1.3 million new vaccinations a day. Links:
Info on states holding 2nd doses in reserve: https://www.brookings.edu/blog/fixgov/2021/02/02/whats-the-hold-up-why-more-vaccines-havent-been-administered/
Current weekly dose shipments and projection of 200 million from Pfizer and Moderna by end of March: https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2021/02/01/962954518/moderna-increases-covid-19-vaccine-shipments-while-pfizer-lags-behind
Johnson and Johnson February distribution estimate: https://www.fiercepharma.com/pharma/as-johnson-johnson-nears-coronavirus-vaccine-data-readout-production-lags-nyt
